turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Nelson Sibron, Appellant versus New York.
Mr. Juviler.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
The New York County District Attorney's office appears as amicus curiae in both the Sibron case number 63 and the Peters number 74.

Time for oral argument has been made available to us from the time allotted to the Sibron case. The interest of amicus as a prosecutor in a major crime infested city is in preserving the constitutionality of the police patrol practices of long standing, which have been codified in the New York stop and frisk statute, the statute that is under attack in both the Sibron and the Peters case.

Whether the question is reached in the Sibron case as Mr. Justice White noted yesterday it must be passed in the Peters case, if it is not reached in the Sibron case and the issues therefore as well as the interests of amicus survive the unusual procedural features of the Sibron case.
We propose to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I ask you if the Peters case was tried on theory that there was a stop and frisk?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yeah I believe it was Your Honor from the testimony of the police officer as to his conduct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That was a rationale of the case, was it, not arrest for probable cause?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: There actually was no express finding by the hearing court, but on a motion to suppress the District Attorney of Westchester County took the position that this was a lawful application of the stop and frisk statute.
He did not seek to justify the officer's conduct on the theory of probable cause.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And that is your argument --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That is our argument here Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Do you defer with the District Attorney for Brooklyn or whatever it is, Kings County with respect to the confession of error in the Sibron case?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: No Mr. Justice we agree with that concession of error.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And on what basis?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: On the basis that the officer lacked reasonable grounds to suspect that the defendant Sibron was behaving in a suspicious manner.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You also do you – what position do you take as to whether the actual frisk or search whichever it maybe as within the scope of statute constitutionally considered?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: We join with Mr. Siegel in contending that this officer was not really applying the stop and frisk statute at all as was clear from his testimony and that the stop and frisk statute did not apply to the conduct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's not quite an answer.
You know the facts in Sibron.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What the officer did and my question to you, your capacity as representing New York County, is whether you consider that, the action of the officer there in that case in Sibron as being within the scope of the stop and, so called stop and frisk statute constitutionally considered?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: We do not.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: In other words then there are two reasons here for the confession of error.

One is a lack of reasonable or the basis for reasonable suspicion and the other that this was not what that officer actually did, that is to say reaching into the man's pocket, was not what permitted by the stop and frisk statute in terms of the constitutional limitations from the application of that statute.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That is exactly our position.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So even if there is reasonable suspicion to within the meaning of the stop and frisk statute, what the officer did it went beyond -- what you think the officer could constitutionally do under the stop and frisk statute?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes that is our position Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that he should not have -- the kind of search that he made exceed constitutional limit?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well on the Peters case --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Which is – may I -- excuse me.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Does the New York stop-and-frisk law apply when a New York officer is living in White Plains and he stops a man in White Plains?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I would have thought not Mr. Justice Marshall until the Court of Appeals' decision in the Peters case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well do you think it does now?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: We would have to construe the Peters case that way, however.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- with Albany?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Rochester, Syracuse, you mean the police officer can go any place in the state and stop somebody and frisk him?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think that as a practical matter that is not a real problem in New York State.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well don't you think Peters is a probable cause.
Don't you think a man has a probable cause if somebody is tinkering with his door, trying to break-in that he has the right to go out and see what's going on?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: He undoubtedly did have a right except that -- we feel that probable cause did not attach until at the very least he felt the hard object in Peter's pocket.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean if he hears somebody tinkering with his door, he looks for people, and he sees a man there, that he hasn't got probable cause to stop it?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: He had probable cause to stop him not--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Question him?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Question him and detain him if necessary to determine what the purpose of this suspect was.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well isn't that what happened there?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That's exactly what happened.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well how do we get to stop and frisk now, he had probable cause?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Because I think probable cause has been used in two senses.

In one sense, its probable cause to believe that a specific person has committed a crime and that is the standard, which justifies actually taking the suspect to the station house and booking him for burglary.
I think perhaps in that sense there was no probable cause at that moment.

However probable cause as Mr. Justice White pointed out in the Camara case in the last term in this Court does not always mean probable cause to believe that a particular person has committed a crime.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You just mean – don't you mean he just had – he had reasonable suspicion?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: He had reasonable suspicion that what he did was reasonable.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He had a reasonable suspicion to stop him, to stop him and detain him momentarily and to frisk him?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Precisely, and if the label of probable cause to detain is placed on this rather than reasonable suspicion, we would quite agree that under either label, what the officer did was reasonable, it was quite reasonable.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: MBut if there is probable cause, they don't get to the stop and frisk statute, is that correct?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Only if the facts fail to show probable cause for an actual arrest and booking of the suspect as the appellants urge in these cases.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You agree that if we think that this was a probable cause case, we are prevented from passing on the constitutionality of stop and frisk statute?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: If there was probable cause to believe that Mr. Peters at the time the officer opened his door was attempting a burglary then it would be unnecessary to reach the constitutional question.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: My understanding to say that the state can rely first on arresting a man for probable cause and if they failed in that that, they can fall back to the stop and frisk law and rely on that because well they didn't have probable cause they did have reasonable suspicion?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think that as a general practice Mr. Chief Justice, the officer relies first on the stop and frisk powers and only subsequently on the arrest powers.

There are undoubtedly borderline cases where in a close case, perhaps Peters is such a case the quantum of evidence does not establish probable cause for arrest, probable cause to believe and yet under all of the facts and circumstances what the officer did was reasonable as that term is employed in the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then you have two bites at it.

The first you can try -- first you can try a probable cause and if it fails in the constitutional sense, you can then fall back on your stop and frisk law and say well at all events we are entitled to stop and frisk him and justify the arrest?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: If the standards of the statute are met.
I think that what Your Honor suggesting is nothing new in the law of Fourth Amendment.

There are cases where an officer will execute a warrant which subsequently proves to have been based on insufficient cause in the officer's affidavit and yet in the course of the officer's subsequent investigation and execution of the warrant, he develops in a lawful manner probable cause for arrest.

Now while the principle, impetus historically for that officer's conduct may have been probable cause, this Court has held -- may have in the warrant, this Court has held that if the warrant does not meet the tests of probable cause under the Fourth Amendment, the officer can, as Your Honor suggests, fall back and I see nothing unreasonable about this under the Fourth Amendment, so long as what the officer did was reasonable and fulfills the requirements of the statute.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, let's try your case, I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No problem.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Let's take a case, if you will, in which the officer has probable cause but he has plenty of time and opportunity to obtain a warrant but without obtaining a warrant acting solely on the basis of probable cause, he arrests the person.
Is that arrest valid as a matter of constitutional law?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Under the decisions of this Court it is, unless the officer has deliberately delayed the arrest for some unworthy purpose such as waiting for the suspect to get to his home, so that he can use the arrest as an excuse for searching the home, incident to arrest.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I ask you this?

If in this Sibron case the officer had reasonable suspicion that this man was carrying narcotics, not probable cause for doing so and had proceeded as he proceeded here, will the case be relieved of error?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think not because based on the findings of the hearing court as expressed in its colloquy with counsel, the court found that the officer's purpose in reaching for Mr. Sibron's pocket was not self-protection, but rather to seize an object that perhaps the suspect was going to throw to the ground and we do not feel that such an action is reasonable.

However, I think there perhaps could be unusual circumstances not raised in any of the cases presently before the Court where a sudden movement by a person detained in a suspicious circumstances, a man who's been observed on tenement roof as the case we cited our brief from the New York files, who was moving from roof to roof late at night and the officer goes up to the tenement roof and stops him and suddenly the man makes an action towards breast pocket, I think there it would be reasonable to eschew in the particular case, the external padding to prevent the additional danger to the officer, but that is not in any of the cases presently before the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would you distinguish the Sibron case from the stop-and-frisk law because in Sibron case, they not only said they were looking for weapons but they actually took other things from him and convicted him on that score?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: They took them Mr. Chief Justice in a manner that was not reasonable.
We do not feel that only weapons maybe admitted in evidence if the officer's maneuver that discovers something other than a weapon was legitimately and reasonably a frisk for a weapon.
But the Sibron case has even further problems than that.

The Sibron case, I think it's clear, does not square with the Court of Appeals' interpretation of the stop-and-frisk statute as expressed in its actual written-in opinions, and we propose to address ourselves to the actual degree of intrusion that the stop-and-frisk statute does permit and to compare that to the constitutional standards for reasonable searches and seizures.
The first, actually the basic provision in this statute is not the frisk.
It's an accident of jurisprudence that the cases that have come before the Court this week have all involved discovery of tangible objects.

As the briefs of the National District Attorneys Association makes clear, they have an appendix with sample cases of detention, the average case that have come to the attention of the lower courts and of this Court on petitions for certiorari, are cases where there's merely a stop, a questioning and a detention and this is really the heart of the stop provision.
The frisk is merely an adjunct to this more essential part of the stop-and-frisk theory which has been codified after long practice in the New York statute.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: When does the frisk end?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: The frisk ends when the officer determines either by this patting -- either by this padding that there are no grounds to suspect that there is a weapon, I pat myself here it's quite obvious that that's the case or when a potential dangerous weapon such as a gun or a gravity knife, a hard object is felt, the officer then of course in all humanity is entitled to examine internally only that specific region of the suspect's person.
Now while the statute uses the word “search” it has been narrowly construed in Judge Keating's opinion in the Peters case to cover only this patting, Your Honors that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What about Taggart?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How about Taggart?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: The Taggart case expressly reaffirms the holding of the Peters case without taking time to read the relevant portion --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you mean that, do you think the New York Court upheld that there must be a preliminary frisk before there's a search -- before even actually reaching to somebody's pocket there must be a --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes, that's correct Mr. Justice, unless there's an extraordinary circumstance such as the Court felt existed in the Taggart case.
Now, we may different with the Court of Appeals in specific fact situations as to what the extraordinary circumstances are.
There, there was specific information relating to a specific weapon at a particular part of the suspect's person.
There was a crowd of children around the suspect.
Now perhaps, it could be argued both way that this is not dangerous enough --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: May I ask Mr. Juviler, conceptually for Fourth Amendment purposes, -- for the Fourth Amendment issue you would – is it your submission that a frisk is or is not a search?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes, it is a search.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: It is a search.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: In the generics --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: May I ask – and then do you also conceptually regard the stop as a seizure the stop and --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Stop and detention is a seizure.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: Well then I gather your argument is that -- what then occurs both as to the stop and the frisk is right, is reasonable?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: It is a seizure that is not unreasonable as that term is used in the Fourth Amendment because the standard --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: The seizure that's not unreasonable and a search that's not reasonable.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: And a search that is not unreasonable.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: That's conceptually your approach?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Precisely because the standards, for reason -- for intrusion of particular types that are cognizable under the Fourth Amendment vary from case to case.

This Court has repeatedly made clear that the standards are flexible, depending upon the circumstances of the particular intrusion, the degree of intrusion and it's the degree of intrusion is proportioned as it is in the stop-frisk-theory to the degree of knowledge that the officer has and this is a reasonable search.
I think the Camara case made that quite clear.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But your concept of this statute authorized police as part of the stop and frisk to put a man in the police car and take him to the police station?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Not at all Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well isn't there a case in New York to that affect –

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think –

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- they on the way to the station, they opened his briefcase and searched it for a weapon or whatever they were looking for?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: The (Inaudible) case to which Your Honor refers was decided prior to the passage of the enactment of the stop-and-frisk bill.
The stop-and-frisk statute says that the officer may search the person.

Now that has been, that has been construed by the police department and by the law enforcement agencies which prepared guidelines, interpreting this law, same agencies that sponsored the law that has been construed as not including opening a briefcase or a ladies handbag.
These are items which reasonably can be taken from the suspect during the detention and placed out of reach.

We do not urge that opening those items is necessary and I don't think that the Court of Appeals would so hold now at least that is unsettled in New York law since the passage of the statute that is before the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To what extent meant for -- in what manner rather and for how long do you consider a detention would be constitutional statute?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think that will depend upon the facts of the case.
Now, the Court of Appeals has stated in the Peters case that the detention is for a short and reasonable period.
They have not had occasion to apply that interpretation to specific cases other than the Peter's case itself, which I think is illustrative of a detention.
We have to be frank.
This is a detention that is reasonable.
The officer caught a suspected burglar on a landing after running after the burglar ran down a flight and half of stairs.
It was reasonable for him to make a brief detention in order to return the suspect to the scene of the suspected crime --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You are arguing the Peters case?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes, I am arguing the Peters case because that's correct Your Honor.

To return Mr. Peters to the scene of the crime, to determine whether indeed the suspicions were correct, whether there had been signs of a break in the apartment opposite, whether the door opposite had forced open.
There are typical cases from actual occurrences in the New York City, which illustrate this.
We cite several in our brief.
The lady whose handbag has been snatched, who tells an officer on the corner that a young man or two young man have run north with a handbag.
The officer sees a young man running two blocks north.
Now he can't take that young man to the station house and book him for a grand larceny.
He doesn't have probable cause to arrest and book, but its perfectly reasonable for him to make a brief detention in order enable a quick confrontation between the suspect and the --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: They asked the suspect question?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: In this instance he could ask questions, I am not sure what purpose --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: Without Miranda warning?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: The Miranda question -- I think the Miranda case, which is written so precisely, left the door open to certain stop-and-frisk situations --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: [Voice Overlap], isn't it?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: And here I gather you are saying that detention is a custodial detention, isn't it?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: It is a custody, but not necessarily Mr. Justice Brennan a custody for purposes of Miranda, because in the Miranda decision, there was compared or there was an explication of that term in same sentence, the suspect is deprived of his freedom in any significant way.
So that the Miranda case acknowledges that there is some restraint on freedom, which is not sufficiently significant to give rise to the Miranda warning.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In Peters didn't the man have him by the collar?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: He had him by the collar, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Its' forced custody.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think in the Peters case [Laughter] I think in the Peters case where there is a caller and a gun open, it wasn't clear from the record whether it was pointed, but a gun open, this is a brief detention, yet it's one which quite reasonably the Miranda warnings now could apply to, although in the Peters case that was not at issue due to the timing of this case.
I don't think that it would be unreasonable in this extraordinary restraint of freedom to apply the Miranda warning.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could you tell me what it was the law enforcement people have in sustaining this -- the right to have what you call this temporary confrontation, which would authorize and enforce the detention for a few moments?

Why is that so much better, produce so much more consequences than just the fact if an officer presence making his presence known, and doing what any officer could do anyway without a statute or without any constitutional problem just walking up to some person asking him a question what are you doing here, without being able to detain him, fellow walked on, that's the end of it?
What real contribution does the ability to forcibly detain him for a moment, for a few moments?
What additional contribution to that to prevention of crime?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: To the actual prevention rather than the apprehension.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This is the major justification --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think that there are some situations where to prevent crime the officer must know or must make reasonable efforts to learn the identity of the suspect.
I think it's impossible and I think it would be undesirable --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But here is standing on the street corner and I suspect you maybe planning some crime and I ask you your name, I can do that without invoking stop-and-frisk and if you tell me I suppose that's -- then I know the name, but if you say none of your business or you can say that and stop-and-frisk --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The courts say that nobody can make you talk about anything.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That's right to stop and question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And again I ask you what contribution does this, this enforced custody for a few moments make to law enforcement or crime prevention?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: In those instances there are with the -- the detention could only be for the length of time to learn the suspect's purpose of being there.

I think that, that alone is limited and as Mr. Justice Marshall noted yesterday, when an officer tells someone to stop and ask them what he is doing and holds him for that period, there is some degree of official authority that is conveyed to the suspect that he must remain there.

I think the prevention is that the officer makes his presence known specifically addressed to that suspect and if he learns his identity, I think he is prevented any (Inaudible) crime in that neighborhood at least in that area.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why does he need some coercive power to help him do this?
Why does he need any new constitutional rule beyond what they're going to -- what already exists?

There is no rules as far as I know against a policeman asking somebody on the a street what his name, what you are doing on the street, and of -- if the fellow now just wants to walk on, he just walks on, the policeman has no power to hold him at least -- so I don't -- I just want to know what extra contribution stopped him, stop-and-frisk authority contributes?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: There are situations of that nature where the suspect has to be stopped Mr. Justice White --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What are those situations?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: We cite a case in our brief that occurred in New York where two men were running out of a bar and they were following a woman who was running out.
Now there may have been a crime here, there may have been an assault, so it's late at night.
The officer had to touch, he had to detain those two men to find out what they were doing.
In other situations where the man is right on the spot, the only --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You think you needed to stop-and-frisk law to do that --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: No as a matter of Mr. Justice White --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That is really responsible.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I don't think we need to stop-and-frisk statute in the strict sense in New York for to preserve this police comment under the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What is the constitutional authority do you need?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: An authority to exercise some restraint.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What do you need the restrain for?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: To, in the one sense to detain a suspect for the length of time --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know that's true, that's just repeating --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: In other instances.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why do you want to detain him for?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: In other instances to enable a confrontation or a clarification of the situation that has arisen and there are many ambiguous situations where a --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: [Inaudible] gentleman doesn't need to talk to you or doesn't need to tell you a word and even under stop-and-frisk law?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Well it has been argued by -- in New York that even to stop someone and keep him there while you are asking what he is doing creates this compulsion which --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, why do you have to keep him there, why do you need to keep him there?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: In most instances -- in many instances you would not beyond the initial just asking his identity and asking what he is doing, but sometimes the suspect may not --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It is a danger that courts will strike down without some -- just a policeman walking up to anyone on the street and say what is your name, do you think?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: No and I think Mr. Justice White if the suspect is in a situation which appears to a potential mugging.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Nothing is going to happen probably as along the policeman is there?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Well, that's the problem.
I don't think we can have policeman on the corner of every street in a high crime area for 24 hours a day and I don't think that would be desirable.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I agree, but at least the fellow knows when the policeman is there, the policeman has got his eye on him?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes when I think of the officer --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And if the fellow refuses to answer a question with or without the stop-and-frisk law, there is nothing the policeman can do about it?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: No, not to make him answer.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Police is not going to get anymore information, the fellow has --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Unless his, unless the majesty of his badge is sufficient he is not, but at least to enforce that majesty he has got to keep the man where he is if he wishes to leave for the duration of time it takes to ask him what he is doing and I think this is traditional police practice.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well I just don't -- still don't get the message in terms of what contribution to law enforcement or over and beyond what presently is you really are getting from stop-and-frisk laws and having them validated under the Fourth Amendment?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Well I think that the more serious problem is the detention of purposes of clarification of an ambiguous situation.
For example the woman screaming and a man coming out the front door late at night or --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Are you sure that the major contribution that [Inaudible] to find weapons?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: It hasn't been -- if that is the purpose it hasn't conceded in the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It sounds like -- in New York last year, didn't you?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Not through the stop-and-frisk statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What did -- then?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: There were 8,000 concealed weapons found in New York City, concealed guns and revolvers which point out the danger to officers in the field, but there is no -- these were not found in enforcement of the stop-and-frisk statute, but once we placed an officer --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Some of them were, weren't they?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Unquestionably.
As a matter of fact we have a table in our -- in the appendix to our brief showing that some of these were found pursuant to the stop-and-frisk statute.

But once the officer is in a situation where his duty compels him to confront an individual who is suspected of a serious crime, it is our position that it's reasonable to touch him, to see whether further danger is required?

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: Mr. Juviler tell me, in New York now that you have the stop-and-frisk law, is the authority of the policeman to stop the ordinary citizen, ask him a question and his name and what he is doing, limited to circumstances where a officer has reasonable suspicion to believe the crime has been committed and he maybe involved.
Is that the only circumstance now and now that you have the statute that the policeman may stop?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think that the additional factor that the statute makes clear is that the policeman can enforce his ability to stop someone, by power, the official power to detain the suspect there.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: But even with the stop-and-frisk, well then an officer may stop me in the street having no reasonable suspicion of anything and ask me my name and what I'm doing.
They do that now that you --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes I think so there is no --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: Well I certainly don't read the appendices to your brief as suggesting that with all those really elaborate regulations that at least New York City has set it?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: Are those what you have in your brief?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: I have the impression now that that's the only option police officer has and he has to justify a stop on the basis of factual statements which will amount to reasonable suspicion, am I wrong about that?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Well I think if the officer is going to do more, I think if the --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: I just want a simple situation where I'm standing in Times Square and he comes up to me and asks me my name and what I'm doing.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: He doesn't need the statute.
But if you're walking --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: I know that may [Inaudible] anymore to that --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: If you are standing --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: Does he have to make a --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Not at all.

But if you walking in Times Square and you resemble a suspect of a murder as occurred in the case in Times Square that we cite, the officer has the power under the statute codifying established power actually to stop your movement.
There is a difference I think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And to detain him?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: And to detain him for purposes of identification in that case and of course in apprehending Mr. Justice White, in apprehending criminals there is in our theory some prevention that is occurring, although this is not the direct effect, but prevention is not the only job of the patrol, although it is the principal job and I think as far as the detention aspect, the detention aspect perhaps is more successful and useful in actually apprehending people who are in ambiguous circumstances where the crime probably has already occurred.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you mean that this statute would not apply unless the man was moving?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That's correct.
It would not be a stop.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, suppose the police officer was going along taking care of his business late at night and he saw a man crouching behind in an alley behind a telegraph pole or something like that, under suspicious circumstances, would you say that this ordinance didn't apply to him just because he wasn't moving?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: No, the ordinance, in the statute would apply Mr. Chief Justice, if the officer was required to detain the person beyond just asking --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you said a little while ago that if this was only to stop them and if they were moving --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I misspoke.
That was ill-considered on my talk.

The statute has been construed Mr. Chief Justice now this term stop has been construed as embodied in the Peters case, as embodying stopping someone who is ambulatory or detaining someone where he is by the official power of the policeman.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well let me ask you this.

You know there have been suggestions that when they stop them and frisk them that they can hold them for, well some people say eight hours, some people say four, some reduce it down to 20 minutes in order I suppose to do what you call detaining him in order to clarify the situation.
Now do you believe any such theory is in accordance with the constitution under this statute?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think it is Your Honor.
Now the statute --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How long would you say that they could detain them?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: The American Law Institute --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I don't care about The American Law Institute, I know what they say.
What are you contending in this Court, that they have the power --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: We are not proposing any specific time limit beyond that which is reasonable.

I think if it gets beyond 20 minutes there has to be a very good reason for the continued detention and in my examination of the cases, a longer detention where this no probable cause to believe is really not necessary for law enforcement.
I think that the ambiguous situations in the great instance can be cleared up as in the cases that we cited in our brief in New York City, in a few minutes.

Now reasonableness under the Fourth Amendment depends on the facts and circumstances of a particular case, just as the standard of an unreasonable delay in arraignment under the Federal Statute is not a minute by minute chronology but something which has to be examined.
We would not -- I cannot conceive of any instance where eight hours would be reasonable.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Can you conceive any situation where there is less than probable cause to take the suspect to the station and put him in the cellar, in custody?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: None whatsoever, that is not authorized by the New York cases and New York law or in our position by the present interpretation of the common law having its --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but your contention is that he can take him right there or can he take him into custody or take him around the city to, say the scene of the crimes?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think he can only take him and it's only necessary and proper to take him to the immediate area where the crime has occurred, I accept I can conceive of one instance which is cited in one of the briefs in the appendix to the National District attorney's brief, where there was a reasonable suspicion that a certain automobile had been engaged in a known burglary and it was seen at the other end of town.

Now the officer on patrol there who received the description saw this car, but he wasn't present at the burglary, he detained the car and in a matter of a few moments a witness and a police officer from the scene were rushed across town to the scene and they established that this was the car and these were the people engaged in the burglary, that was –

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Suppose the rush had been the other way?
Suppose they had taken the suspect across the city for people to look at him and so forth?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think that would be reasonable as in the case of the purse snatch for example where you had a distraught woman whose purse was snatched and she hysterically gave a description to the officer, I think it's reasonable for the suspect to be brought back to the scene or the woman screaming in the window up above and a man is stopped down here.

I think that, and in the Peters case where the burglary suspect was brought from the fifth floor landing up to the sixth floor, I think this is a very limited type of detention which doesn't include the handcuffs, the cell bars, the booking and the crowded police station and that is not needed and it's not authorized by the New York cases or the Court of Appeals cases and the statute in New York.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The suspect can be sequestered as well in police car with two or three police officers and he can't be in the station, can't he?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes I think the problem here is actually one not of the place, but of the degree of force or official coercion that is needed and I think putting someone in the police car its not so much where he is, but that this is a use of a greater degree of force or official restraint than just asking him to remain where he was, where he is while the radio call that he made to see whether the car is stolen, for example.
I think that is the traditional police practice.

I think there is a certain extent Mr. Justice Warren where these cases as in all search and seizure cases under the Fourth Amendment have to be reviewed on a case by case basis deepening on a facts of the particular case and while there are always borderline situations --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Even to the extent of abandoning probable cause?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: To the extent probable cause is not abandoned Mr. Chief Justice I think that in the established --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Just relaxed in the opinion of the police?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: In the customary law, in the decisions of every court in the lower courts that have reached this including the Federal courts and in the common law probable cause to believe to book someone and arrest him is not required for a minimal limited detention of the type that is authorized by the New York statute.

Undoubtedly, there will be cases arising where the detention goes beyond those limits as there are cases in every police rule under the Fourth Amendment and I think the courts and this Court are well-equipped to point out to the police the true standards and the proper boundaries as the cases arrive.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: Mr. Juviler, may I ask this, under this statute is it contemplated that an officer who stops me on the street may before he says anything, frisk me.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes, it is contemplated --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: He may just stop me and before he asks my name or anything else, he frisks me?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: He could not stop Your Honor but he could stop someone with --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: I wonder why he couldn't?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: -- reasonably suspected of a serious crime.
Now, if Your Honor, if the officer --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: That's the only time then in the situation where there isn't --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: -- reasonable suspicion he may not frisk, is that --?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Absolutely, the statute is unequivocal in that respect and it has been so construed in the Peters case.
There's no way to read the statute any other way.
You can't just go and ask someone's name who is not under a reasonable suspicion and frisk him, it's absolutely unauthorized.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You can go and ask him without reasonable suspicion what his name is?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: But if you do have reasonable suspicion then without asking him any questions you may immediately frisk him?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes, because the frisk often is at the initial stages --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And it has to be.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Of the questioning and --

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: Well certainly if the justification for the frisk is --

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: -- that the officer not be killed or injured.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: Yes, and there were some instances where --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I have a great problem with that.
The officer has suspicion that this man is engaged in selling narcotics and he is the most casual milk toast type of guy you ever laid eyes on.
So he has the right to frisk him or isn't it true that he only gets the right to frisk if he reasonably thinks his life is in danger?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: The latter, he must reasonably suspect that his life is or limb is in danger.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that's the limit, that's the limit?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: That is the limit.
The statute doesn't authorize a frisk in every instance and it hasn't been despite the claims that have been made at this Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But in the Peters case again -- but in the Peters case was the officer in danger of his life?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think so.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He has to chase the man down two flights of stairs to frisk him?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think it's a dangerous.
I think he chased him so that he could stop him and bring him back to the scene.

I think he chased Mr. Peter so that he could stop him and bring him back to the scene and see what happen and I think it would have been unreasonable to expect the officer to do that without making a very minimal self-protective inquiry.
Now if the officer had been shot and killed that would have been impossible to balance against the number of people who are touched in those circumstances.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I'm not -- that officer did act reasonably in the circumstances, he didn't even act with probable cause, but I understood you to say a moment ago absolutely this stop-and-frisk ordinance was limited to instances where the officer thought his life was in danger.

Now in this case, in the Peters case, he walked out of -- these men were tiptoeing along the hall and he opened his door and banged it and when they heard the bang they ran, and ran down to couple of flights of stairs and he chased them and caught them.

Now, in applying the stop-and-frisk law you have to say that officer did that because he thought his life was in danger, would you, wasn't, didn't he do that because he thought these men were burglars and he detained them because he thought they were burglars.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: So that's why he detained them and I think he frisked them --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, well isn't that a question of probable cause.

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: I think it's a problem of reasonableness.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, reasonableness of frisk, under our Constitution is been said to be probable cause, isn't it?

turn.speaker: michael_juviler
turn.label: Mr. Michael Juviler
turn.text: It's probable cause to believe in the context of an actual arrest and it's context of other searches or intrusions, probable cause can just mean reasonableness that was the express language of a majority of this Court in the Camara case.
I think that the probable cause standard which is stated in the Fourth Amendment applicable to warrants is not designed to cover every intrusion of any kind and the Court has repeatedly so held.
That is just one example, singled out by the framers because there was a particular evil that was aimed at that required the specification of that one example of reasonableness.
And whether the Court should consider this probable cause or consider it a search or seizure that is not unreasonable.

I think the ultimate result is that what the officer did in this case and many other cases that it represents was reasonable and if it's reasonable the conduct should not be disapproved by the Court and evidence obtained in this reasonable manner under traditional rulings is admissible in Court.

turn.speaker: gretchen_white_oberman
turn.label: Ms. Gretchen White Oberman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, you are --

turn.speaker: gretchen_white_oberman
turn.label: Ms. Gretchen White Oberman
turn.text: -- may it please the Court.
I must speak to the question of mootness which was not raised at any stage of this case before yesterday.
I have a minute and 40 seconds left and I have a minute and 40 seconds argument prepared.
Jurisdiction was noted in this case before this Court's decisions in Jacobs and Tenenbaum against New York and before this Court's decision in See against Seattle.
In all these cases there were suspended fines or non-felony sentences which could not be executed at a later date.
Under Jacobs and Tenenbaum, Sibron is moot, under See against Seattle it is not.
The problem of mootness is of particular concern in New York where it's virtually impossible for an appellant in New York to obtain bail pending appeal and thus preserve this case for Federal review.
Moreover, under Section 555 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, bail on appeal is prohibited to one situated as well as Sibron.

This Court should reconsider Jacobs and Tenenbaum or at least limit them to cases that did not become moot because of the petitioner's indigence or because of the state's limitation upon the right to bail pending appeal.
The confession of error in this case points up the weakness of the Jacobs and Tenenbaum rule.
Sibron is a case concededly wrongly decided which if dismissed will never be set right.
On the District Attorney's concession, we have stated that our only interest as advocate for Sibron is to obtain making sure of his conviction.

Our response to questioning yesterday stems from our doubt as to this Court's power to except one District Attorney's concession that the New York Court of Appeals erred not once but twice in holding that it's own statute applied to this case and also from our conviction that the non-bailable petty offenders of New York should be able to rely not only on the conscience of one man in a busy District Attorney's office to see that they get justice, but on the entire judicial system of the State of New York especially where the consent is not upon the New York Courts within its own Court system.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: gretchen_white_oberman
turn.label: Ms. Gretchen White Oberman
turn.text: May we file a brief on mootness, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, you may.
You may respond if you wish to Mr. Siegel.

turn.speaker: gretchen_white_oberman
turn.label: Ms. Gretchen White Oberman
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 74 -- I suggest you do that very properly because we're in a longtime schedule, it's been two, three days, if you do that.

turn.speaker: gretchen_white_oberman
turn.label: Ms. Gretchen White Oberman
turn.text: Thank you Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You may have it type written instead of printed if you wish?

turn.speaker: gretchen_white_oberman
turn.label: Ms. Gretchen White Oberman
turn.text: Thank you Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 74 John Francis Peters versus New York. Mr. Friedman.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, members of the Court.

May it please the Court, this cause is before the Court today on direct appeal from a judgment of the New York State Court of Appeals, which judgment confirmed the defendant's conviction for the illegal possession of burglar's tools.

On this appeal, the defendant contends that a certain search of this person and the seizure of evidence there from constituted an unreasonable search and seizure of his person in violation of his rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.
In this case, as in the Sibron case, the validity of a state statute, namely Section 180 (a) of the New York Code of Criminal Procedure has been drawn into question.
Additionally there have been raised in this case broad questions, which concern the rights of our citizenry to move about freely without undue police interference.
May I briefly set forth the factual material, underlying the events in this case?

The appellant was arrested in the City of Mount Vernon in New York on July 10, 1964 at or about 1 pm on that day by a man by the name of Lasky who at that time was a police officer attached to the Police Department of the City of New York.

On a preliminary hearing in the City of Mount Vernon, officer Lasky testified that at the time in question he resided in the six-floor apartment of a very large multiple dwelling, located in the City of Mount Vernon and that approximately at 1 pm on that day he had finished taking a shower, or he was in the process of taking a shower, when he heard some noise outside of his apartment door.
He testified that he went to the peephole of his apartment door, looked out and then he saw two men whom he did not recognize, tiptoeing to the common hallway of the premises.

Then his testimony was that he made a telephone call and that he put some clothing on, again looked through the peephole of the door, saw these two men in the common hallway tiptoeing and that he left his apartment with his drawn service revolver in hand.

And then he heard the two men descending the staircase, common stairway of the building and he pursued them and that he apprehended the defendant at a point midway between the fourth and fifth floor landings of the common stairway of the premises.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I interrupt just a moment?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Wasn't there a little more to the facts on that, didn't he say that as soon as he came -- when he came out of his door, he slammed the door deliberately to see what affect it would have on them and when they heard that slamming of the door, they ran, ran downstairs, am I wrong in that?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: My recollection of the testimony Mr. Chief Justice is somewhat different, though it maybe a slight difference.
I don't believe that he testified that he slammed the door for that purpose.
He may have testified that he slammed his door and heard them exiting hastily, but I don't believe that it was done for that purpose or that there was any testimony in the record to that effect.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is it your position that these facts do not constitute probable cause for an arrest?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Justice Fortas it is not only my position, but it was the New York Court of Appeals' position because --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I understand that.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: -- in referring to this case later on in the Taggart case when they summarized all of their decisions as to what had gone before, they say that in 20 N.Y.2d 335, that, “And even in People v. Peters, where the officer initially frisked the defendant and felt something hard, this Court held that the officer did not have "probable cause" to make the arrest until he actually reached into the defendant's pocket, withdrew, and identified the burglars' tools.”
So this has been conceded by the People and reflects the opinion of the Court of Appeals additionally.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Some of us may feel very pleased of the very high standards of the New York Court of Appeals in this instance, but when you look at in terms of the Fourth Amendment, you regard this as a case of probable cause?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Yes Your Honor because --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You do?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: That is not a case of probable cause.

Yes I do regard it as not coming up to the level of probable cause, because in the first instance whatever suspicions may have been in the police officer's mind, there is nothing factually in the record which gives rise to the inference of the commission of any crime or the imminence of the commission of any crime.

If we examine the totality of his observations, he saw two men tiptoeing in the hallway and while this may not be legitimately normal conduct as I believe Judge Galloway in the County Court decision denying suppression, I believe that was Judge Galloway's language, “I maintain that every conduct that one observes which is not perfectly normal, perfectly legitimate does not necessarily give rise to probable cause.”

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well Mr. Friedman didn't he first hear first somebody or a sound that seemed to purport that somebody was tampering with his door?
Is that right or wrong?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall I must say that, that is wrong in the sense that he testified that he heard some noise at or outside of his door, but there was no testimony that there was any tampering with any door and as a matter of fact --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He heard a sound outside of his door which obviously was not a normal sound or he wouldn't have attracted, correct?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: What attracted the police officer, I don't know, but there's --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well I assume the police officer didn't every minute on the minute look out for people.
Can I assume that?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall you're quite correct in the assumption, but I don't think that necessarily follows that there was any attempt to tamper with his door.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But he heard a sound, which attracted his attention at or near his door.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And then he looked out the peephole and saw two men tiptoeing around.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: That is quite correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that doesn't raise any suspicion in your mind?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: I said that it may raise suspicion, but it would embrace probable cause for the type of conduct ensued.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: As the result of this suspicion he went out to try to find out what was going on outside of his doorway.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: That was his right --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And he shut the door and lo and behold he's seeing two men took off, he still doesn't have any suspicion about anything.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: No, Your Honor I agree that he does have suspicions, but I disagree with the proposition that he has probable cause to believe that there was a crime, that a crime had committed, or was about to be committed.
As a matter of fact when officer Lasky grabbed this appellant by the collar and dragged him down half a flight of stairs and asked him what he was doing in the building.

He said that he was there for the purpose of visiting his girlfriend and upon being pressed for the name of the woman in question, the defendant said he didn't wish to reveal the name of the woman in question because she was a married woman and that explanation at least on the face of the explanation is consistent with tiptoeing through a common hallway of a large multiple dwelling, where there a 120 families.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the officer did not believe it?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Excuse me?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The man might not believe the --

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Yes, but I don't think that every time a police officer doesn't believe an explanation given by a person, he rudely seizes by the collar at gunpoint that he's entitled to take further action because --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And it also might not be true, the man might be there tiptoeing around with a set of burglar tools in his pocket?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: That might very well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It might be possible?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: It might very well be possible, but on the other hand in looking at the problem from the protection of our citizenry in general, the man might be a man who was not engaged in any criminal activity whatsoever, so that if we accept the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean in [Attempt to Laughter] the burglary type?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: In the burglary type, [Attempt to Laughter] if we accept the construction of the statute, given by the New York Court of Appeals in this case, without looking at what the fruits of the search actually did produce in this case and we look at the facts which preceded the search, we accept a construction which permits a police officer on intuitive hunch or guess as opposed to probable cause with respect to a commission of a crime, to seize the person probably at gunpoint, search him without his consent and in the absence of any, overt act of criminality.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Friedman I have always a problem about reading records in this area, but here the policeman heard this noise, words -- exact instruments to describe the noise, but the policeman heard a noise and he picked up the telephone and he called the local police, didn't he?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now then that suggests to the reasonable mind that it was not the noise of somebody walking through the hall and going to a cocktail party, because I suppose a policemen, one may assume the policemen are considered they call a policeman and don't put in alliance for no reason at all.

Then the policeman who testified here got his service revolver and finally went charging, after making this telephone call and went charging out of his door with a drawn revolver and it seems to me that there should have been a lunacy inquiry about this policeman or that one has to read this with some with authority here and assume that these noises were something more than just a noise that they consider a citizen tiptoeing down the halls so it wouldn't disturb people having a siesta.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Justice Fortas, it is true the record does not reveal preciously what the sound was that the officer heard and perhaps that is unfortunate that a record comes to the Court and that's --.

turn.speaker: justice_berannan
turn.label: Mr. Justice Berannan
turn.text: Well it did say it was a noise at the door.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: At the door that is correct Mr. Justice Brennan, but may I say that in a situation like this it is appellant's contention that where you have suspicion which does not rise to probable cause that the proper police action and one which he does not even use the statutory authority for, could have consisted very reasonably in observing what these two men were doing possibly following them and possibly demanding an explanation without the use of the force of their presence in the building and if the purpose was to deter a burglary, if that was his objective in mind at that juncture he would be have accomplished his purpose, but I don't think the record shows that, that was his purpose at all, because the record shows that when he removed this plastic envelope from the defendant's pocket it was an opaque envelope that was sealed.

So that at this moment in time when you have the envelope taken from the defendant he had no knowledge as to the contents yet, but in any event he had no fear for his life because the defendant had no hard object at that point.

At a later point in time the record shows he opened up the envelope in order to discover what was inside of it which leaves one to the inescapable conclusion that the search of the appellant was for the primary purpose of exploring for evidence.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What was in the envelope?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: In the envelope it is conceded that there were tools to the commission of burglary.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What was it?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Some Allen wrench and some picks I believe were described in the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Specifically what?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Presumably.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well that's what they use for --

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: I would presume that they were because it was conceded below that the issue in this case dealt with the reasonableness of the search and seizure vis-à-vis was there probably cause where we can see -- where we contended on the preliminary motions that probable cause does not exist in this case and where the courts agree that -- New York Courts agree the probably cause did not exist and decided this case on the basis of the statute Section 188 and on the basis of case law having substantial equivalent, substantive equivalent of the statute and I refer to People v. Rivera which is found in 14 N.Y.2d I believe.

And all events if we look at the statute, if I might turn my directions to that for a moment, you have a situation where the courts seek to substitute a standard of what is described in the statute as reasonable suspicion or probable cause.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you this when -- what is the difference between reasonable suspicion and probable cause?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Well as I apprehend the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That words that contest.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: As I apprehend the distinction as is outlined by the New York Court of Appeals and really that is the only basis that I can have for an opinion as to the meaning of reasonable suspicion as opposed to probable cause, reasonable suspicion calls for the intuitive appraisal of a police officer that a crime has been committed or is about to be committed and in the words -- exact words of the Court of Appeals, I believe it was Judge Keating's words which said that the standard of knowledge, the quantum of knowledge that the police officer has at that juncture when he entertains a reasonable suspicion is lower on the scale of criminal activity then would be required in a probable cause case so that you are dealing with a standard which is less than probable cause in a constitutional sense as we have known --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now does the constitution of -- any constitutional sense that Federal questioning --

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose one who had interpreted the Federal law see no difference constitutionally speaking between the reasonable suspicion and the probable cause?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Well I think at this point the construction of the statute as construed by the New York Court of Appeals is the issue, I would take no quarrel with the New York Court of Appeals how they construe it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But we have to construe it according to the Federal meaning of it since this is a comparison of whether reasonable suspicion means probably cause, so the New Court did say that.
The did Court did find imaginary distinction.

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Justice, I would say that this Court has to accept the construction of a statute as it comes to this Court from the highest State Court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On the constitutional basis?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Yes and if the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Don't we have to construe what probable cause means?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: I believe this Court has --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or if we said that probable cause as a matter of reasonable suspicion, what's the meaning?

turn.speaker: robert_stuart_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Robert Stuart Friedman
turn.text: Yes, but then we would be dealing with the same quantum of evidence and knowledge which we have known in traditional causes -- in probable cause cases and the Court of Appeals has settled for something less and its conception here what reasonable suspicion means and this appellant states that we -- and its our position that we cancel something for probable cause.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
